Authors:
Thomas Lecocq, Nicolas Brasero, Thibaut De Meulemeester ,
Denis Michez, Simon Dellicour, Patrick Lhomme, Roland de Jonghe, Irena
Valterova, Pierre Rasmont
Title:
Integrative taxonomic approach to assess the taxonomic status
of insular bumblebees: implication on Corsican bumblebee
conservation
Keywords:
Integrative taxonomy, conservation, Island, Corsica,
bumblebees
Abstract:
Islands are well-known biodiversity hotspots that host a
high diversity of endemic species. Unfortunately, insular taxa suffer
from high rates of extinction and endangerment. Numerous conservation
plans are developed to safeguard a wide range of insular taxa. These
conservation plans are often assessed on the basis of occurrence and
proportion of endemic species. However, species characterization is
still confusing and controversial. From a practical point of view, these
disagreements make difficult to government agencies and nongovernment
organizations to evaluate the validity of taxonomic status in the
listing process for conservation. By following an integrative taxonomic
approach, the present study includes molecular, chemical and
morphological criteria to establish the taxonomic status of eight
insular bumblebee taxa from the Corsica Island. Six are Corsican
endemics (Bombus corsicola, B. hortorum jonghei, B. perezi, B.
pereziellus, B. renardi, and B. xanthopus) while the two last are
similar to adjacent continental populations (B. barbutellus, and B.
pascuorum). For each taxa, we characterize the differentiation of
Corsican vs.Â mainland nearest parent (i) in DNA sequences (nuclear and
mitochondrial genes, (1622 bp) and (ii) in the chemical composition of
cephalic labial gland secretions (CLGS), a ecochemical trait for
bumblebees species discrimination. Our results show a morphological
differentiation (color pattern) and genetic divergence of all Corsican
endemics. Likewise, our comparative chemical analyses of CLGS indicate
that four Corsican endemics are differentiated from the mainland.
Phylogenetic analyses, DNA sequence-based species automatic delimitation
approach, and comparative chemical studies show that two Corsican taxa
can be considered as endemic species while four other are considered as
subspecies. We advocate the importance to conserve the endemic
subspecies as well as endemic species of the Corsican bumblebee fauna,
the largest fauna of bumblebee endemic taxa in West-Palearctic
region.
